CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 2, 1960, pg. 3 reads: "Picket Line Here Protests Dixie Bias - While a curious throng of onlookers, including some self-styled leaders of the fight for civil rights, watched with interest, approximately 80 men, women and youths threw an effective picket line around the downtown Woolworth store here, in protest against the chain company's acquiescence to the insulting segregation policy at its lunch counters in South...Lower right photo, Pitt and Chatham students, respectively, march fearlessly and with pride in behalf of their fellow students who are gallantly fighting the "Dixie cancer." The cute, dimpled Chatham student is Marva Jo Hord, former Schenley High honor student...Among those unafraid to be counted in the picket line were Atty. Henry R. Smith, state president of the NAACP; Dr. Hugh Cleland, Pitt history professor; Peter D. Hammond, Pitt anthropology professor; the Revs. J.B. Cayce, Ebenezer Baptist Church; Churchill Carter, Park Place AME, Homestead; R. H. Reid, Payne Chapel AME, Duquesne, and J.G. Jarris, Bethel AME, Pittsburgh; Mrs. Marion B. Jordon, Mrs. Paul Knitt, James O. Dougan, Matthew Moore, Regis Bobonis, and The Courier's George E. Barbour and Frank E. Bolden - Harris Photos
TitMainTitle: Women, including Marva Jo Hord (Harris), protesting outside of Woolworth's carrying signs reading "A protest against this co. policy in the south," "Chatham students protest civil rights violation," and "Chatham students protest Woolworth lunch counter segregation," Smithfield Street and Sixth Avenue, Downtown
